clinical_study.brief_title: Pain Management for Head and Neck Cancer Survivors
clinical_study.official_title: Survivors of Head and Neck Cancer: Optimizing Pain Management

brief_summary.textblock: This clinical trial improves an existing pain management program and tests its effect on head and neck cancer survivors. This trial aims to find a better program to improve pain-related physical functioning, mood, and quality of life in a sample of individuals who have undergone treatment for head and neck cancer.

detailed_description.textblock:
PRIMARY OBJECTIVES:
I. Adapt an existing telehealth pain management intervention to target improvement of pain-related physical functioning, mood, substance use, and quality of life in a local sample of veteran head and neck cancer (HNC) survivors.
II. Conduct a pilot of the adapted intervention to examine the feasibility (accrual, adherence, attrition) and acceptability (participant satisfaction) that will form the basis of a well-powered, randomized clinical trial submitted for funding to the National Institutes of Health (NIH), American Cancer Society (ACS), or Veterans Affairs (VA).
OUTLINE:
Patients attend 5 sessions of Mobile Pain Coping Skills Training for 45 minutes each over 8 weeks.
After completion of study, patients are followed up at 2 months.

primary_outcome.description: Will be assessed by Brief Pain Inventory. Will be assessed as 1-4=mild pain; 5-6 moderate pain; 7-10 severe pain.
Will be assessed by the Patient Health Questionnaire. Scores of 5, 10, 15, and 20 represent point scale for mild, moderate, moderately severe and severe depression, respectively.
Will be assessed by the Chronic Pain Self-Efficacy Scale.

secondary_outcome.description: Will be assessed by the PENN Cravings Questionnaire. Total score >20 were considered to meet the threshold of craving, 15-20 were considered subthreshold, and <15 were considered non-cravers.

secondary_outcome.measure: Head and neck cancer related quality of life
secondary_outcome.description: Will be assessed by the University of Michigan Quality of Life Questionnaire.

other_outcome.description: Will be assessed via patient report.
Will be assessed using the Chronic Opioid Misuse Measure (COMM). A score of 9 or greater is suggestive of current problematic drug-related behaviors.

Post-intervention, patients will be asked to rate satisfaction with the program, perception of utility with pain management, using a Likert-scale. Will inquire about patients' experiences participating in the intervention, perceived burden of participation, perception of the intervention utility, ease of use of the associated technology, and suggestions for improving the intervention.

arm_group.arm_group_label: Supportive care (Mobile Pain Coping Skills Training)
arm_group.description: Patients attend 5 sessions of Mobile Pain Coping Skills Training for 45 minutes each over 8 weeks.

intervention.description: Attend Mobile Pain Coping Skills Training
intervention.arm_group_label: Supportive care (Mobile Pain Coping Skills Training)
Supportive care (Mobile Pain Coping Skills Training)
Supportive care (Mobile Pain Coping Skills Training)

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Clinically confirmed diagnosis of HNC for which they have completed curative cancer treatment at the VA hospital or Oregon Health & Science University (OHSU) within the 6-24 months following treatment
- Self-reported current pain of 4 or higher, using the 0-10 Numeric Pain Rating (NRS) (0="no pain" to 10="the worst pain imaginable")
- Self-report of pain 4 or higher on two occasions, more than three weeks apart, since the completion of curative treatment
Exclusion Criteria:
- Enrolled in hospice
- Have substantial hearing or visual difficulties that would impair ability to participate
- Have inadequate cognitive functioning as indicated by medical record review and/or interactions with clinical staff. If needed we can follow up with the St. Louis University Mental State Examination (score of < 22/30) (SLUMS); or
- Have untreated severe psychiatric illness that would impact the ability to consent and participate in the intervention
